description: [Status: stable] [Name: invalid-class-name] [Message: Class name {name} should use CapWords convention] What it does Checks for class names that do not follow the CamelCase convention. Why is this bad? PEP 8 recommends the use of the CapWords (or CamelCase) convention for class names: Class names should normally use the CapWords convention. The naming convention for functions may be used instead in cases where the interface is documented and used primarily as a callable. Note that there is a separate convention for builtin names: most builtin names are single words (or two words run together), with the CapWords convention used only for exception names and builtin constants. Example class my_class: pass Use instead: class MyClass: pass

lint.pep8-naming.ignore-names.option_description:
A list of names (or patterns) to ignore when considering pep8-naming violations.

Supports glob patterns. For example, to ignore all names starting with test_
or ending with _test, you could use ignore-names = ["test_*", "*_test"].
For more information on the glob syntax, refer to the globset documentation.



Example usage:

pyproject.tomlruff.toml


[tool.ruff.lint.pep8-naming]
ignore-names = ["callMethod"]



[lint.pep8-naming]
ignore-names = ["callMethod"]

lint.pep8-naming.extend-ignore-names.option_description:
Additional names (or patterns) to ignore when considering pep8-naming violations,
in addition to those included in ignore-names.

Supports glob patterns. For example, to ignore all names starting with test_
or ending with _test, you could use ignore-names = ["test_*", "*_test"].
For more information on the glob syntax, refer to the globset documentation.



Example usage:

pyproject.tomlruff.toml


[tool.ruff.lint.pep8-naming]
extend-ignore-names = ["callMethod"]



[lint.pep8-naming]
extend-ignore-names = ["callMethod"]
